title: ENG09_pt 1: 2.6 Literacy Narrative: How does language define us? | SVHS

mainContent.text:
2.6 Literacy Narrative: How does language define us?

        Completion requirements
        



The story of language is connected to identity

In her famous literacy narrative "Mother Tongue," Chinese-American author Amy Tan tells of learning the "four Englishes" from her non-native speaking Chinese mother: the "simple" and "broken" spoken informally at home and the "limited" and "proper" spoken
    in public.  
As you read Amy Tan's literacy narrative, try to connect to how Jin Wang and Wei-Chen Sun, also from San Francisco's Chinatown,  learn the languages needed to assimilate (or fit in) to a new culture, a new school, and new relationships. What
    mistakes do Jin and Wei-Chen make publicly and privately? Are they ashamed of their native language or mother tongue? What ways of speaking or writing help them learn to be humble and accept their language, and therefore, their identity?
     
Who has shaped you in meeting new people and traveling to new places? What types of languages do you speak and write? Even if you are monolingual (speak only one language), there are many languages within languages. Don't you speak differently
    to your friends (privately) than you do adults (publicly)? How do you speak to new people you've just met? How might you write to your boss at work? All of these ways of speaking and writing to new audiences are, in effect, different
    literacies. We all use different appeals, tones, and ranges of formal and informal language to meet these rhetorical situations.

Assignment:  
Read "Mother Tongue" by Amy Tan.

Watch the following videos after you read the essay:
